what are the chords on "supposed to be, whoa" in more than a dream

"supposed to be" is Gmaj7 over A. "whoa" in the first chorus is generally supposed to feel like Fsus2 over A, except with bass movement. so i guess there's no point in saying it's F/A specifically, because the bass seems to wander through Fmaj pentatonic i suppose. In the last chorus, however, on the the "whoa", there's 3 chords. if you consider 3 melody notes (A, G, F) double each one a fourth above and a major 3rd above. so it's A C# D, then G B C, then F A Bb. I'm sure there were bass notes designated there also, but, on the recording, the bass seems to wander out for a bagel in that moment

Hi i wanted to try and make a sort of breakdown of Fly Around cause I really wanted to see what you'd think of it. Okay anyway here i go wish me luck
"i walk over the earth in special sandals
i took those sandals off
now i can fly around"
'Special sandals' may represent something holding you down.. It's description as "special" may be found in a less positive light than tonally suggested, or perhaps could be found rather as just a catchy verbally-'adjacent adjective' ..or perhaps entirely as just a magical item betrothed upon our main character that upon removal awakens their inner super-power of flight- I'm not entirely sure and I'd love to hear your thoughts on the line.

all roads lead to musical happiness. start anywhere. after writing a lot of songs, you look for the roads less traveled. perhaps i'm trying to create something extremely "prose" and then let the joys of music prove that you can musicify anything, including the proseyest things. by "prosey" i suppose i mean like not written with any expected rhythm or rhyme scheme. if you looked at the lyrics alone you probably wouldn't even assume it was a song. also the flying comes as a surprise. i'm sure i genuinely wasn't even expecting the flying by the time i'd reached "sandals." even though i'm sure i came up with the whole line just about in real time. So in other words, basically i'm just attempting to enjoy the sensation of dreaming while awake. or at least try my best to achieve that

"some people wonder why the sun is not very bright"
my arms ar e much too tired for this conversation"
I'll come back to this line momentarily!
"i travel the distance
in between where i was and where i would like to be a little later"
I suppose this is a long poetic way of saying I went from here to there (presumably whilst flying, of course)

i wasn't necessarily thinking of flying here. it looks like i was just continuing the same soft prosey strategy. again, i could have been as late as "was" and still had no idea exactly *when* (rhythmically) the line might end. and yet i certainly knew what the meaning of the phrase was by the time i hit "travel the distance". the rest of the line is sort of an exercise in free will to see how many times i could surprise myself with number of syllables the sentence turned out to actually have. despite already knowing from the beginning of the line what information it was going to be paraphrasing (travel from point A to point B)

"the sky is falling"
Okay this gets interesting-
i think it's the least interesting part so far. sounds like it was lifted from some nursery rhyme

in your video "gonna clean my room" the song goes that you'll clean your room after the 'sun burns out' and the 'sky falls down' so there's an interesting connection, added on top of that 'sun is not very bright' coincided with 'sun burns out.'

the sky and sun have been up there all my life. so they both commonly come to mind often. so that 'connection' is probably shared by a huge percentage of my songs. unless i'm deliberately trying to cut back

And another cool thing- 'sun burns out and the sky falls down' is also pretty similar to the line from 'mount saint helens' - 'sun falls down and the sky burns out.' I suppose in general a lot of your music conveys apocalyptic emotions and references so perhaps 'sun is not ver y bright' and 'the sky is falling' were merely intuition ..but then I thought deeper.. the song as a whole... And I realized given all the present themes of the future being upon us and reconciling that with the memories of our past, maybe all this really does take place farther along upon a vast timeline, where the sun may really be slowly dying out and no longer radiates light to the extent of our own. And all this talk of the sun and skies still connects it all back to 'flying around'. His arms are supposedly too tired to talk about it, maybe from flying, or maybe even because he doesn't want to talk about it.
"the sky is larger 
than any sky can be"
This builds on 'sky is falling" describing how unimaginably and unbelievably vast the sky truly is, presumably as seen from the perspective of one flying across it.

i guarantee i was not thinking about flying at this point. given the carefree attitude of this song, i'd assume that pretty much everything in here so far, including the sandals, sky, the flying, are part of a floaty collage of aesthetics here

"oo, ah, oh, ee
my calendar is telling me it's the future"
I remember you talking about this sorta lyrical device in an answer to a question about balancing phrases and musical non-words, and this truly masters that- the punch and impact in this chorus is really felt.

in addition to that technique, i also used another balancing trick on a doubled timescale here, which is where half the page is filled with words (etc), and the other half of the page just has 1 word. (future). so it sort of invokes a comparison of "everything to 1". which is an interesting ratio for those following along mathematically

"somewhere there's a second scene
with characters that never speak
but you still know exactly what they mean
and you still know exactly what the story will be" 
This 'second scene' musically illustrates a depiction of characters who despite never exchanging any dialogue you still know what they are saying, the way a drawing conveys a story without any words.
"i travel the world without my blanket
so when i'm feeling tired
i can just... fly around"
This is very tongue-in-cheek contradictory all around yet elicits such powerful feelings and is honestly really musically beautiful.

seems like a double negative is achieved in that line somehow. again probably attempting to dream while i'm awake. sometimes saying things backwards is a nice way to throw off the boring non-dreaming part of the brain. which i suppose would be the frontal lobe for those of you following along neurologically

"most people wonder if the moon is part of the sky
or if it's just a decoration added later"
This line retains the themes of out-of-our-world observations of the sun and skies from the previous verses upon titularly flying around. It also retains a merit of scientific accuracy given as you've said in your own words: ''holy sh*t we just got hit with another ball of flaming rocks- and it kind of made a mess. which is🎶now the moon🎶.' In essence this line maybe asks the question 'is the moon really real?' And while being musically a melodic 'echo' of 'sun is not very bright'

i can tell you that the musical/lyrical echo is the primary reason for this line's existence. i guess it's that part of the second verse where it's time to be mildly responsible in the songwriting. it echoes the 'some people wonder', and instead of "sun" it's "moon", which felt like the standard verse 1 to 2 transferrence. and the rest of the line is just the best option i could come up with for finishing it. it also seems to generally play a 3rd above the first verse's line, (not to mention an actual harmony added above it here) which playes into the mention of 'decoration', and it is 'later' in 2 ways actually, because the this verse's line comes later than the first, but, also because the vocal singing the higher harmony here came later than the lead
the question simultaneously implies the same feeling the statement 'the sky is larger than any sky ca n be' does.
possibly true

"oo, ah, oh, ee
my galaxy is spinning toward the future"
Continuing to tie in visualizations of beyond-our-world intergalactic wonders, this line ties in both time and space.
i recall 'galaxy' being some kind of freudian slip at one point while i was running through the first bridge. so i earmarked it for the second

"somewhere in the 7th scene
when no one understands the point of view
that you now find so familiar"
'7th scene' captures the feeling that we've moved on a little bit further into this story's future
true

and also makes for a zesty rhyme with '2nd scene.' But really this line truly speaks for itself- it finds this whole analysis to be ironic. We can't fully understand the point of view that the artist finds so familiar. But that's the beauty of storytelling and songwriting.

i can tell you that a big part of the reason this line is built the way it is is to juggle the rhythm and surprise myself as much as possible. basically to keep the sentence going as long as possible, causing a long string of 'challenges' to the rhythm and then see if i can maneuver it into a musically and linguistically coherent landing. it's kind of like when pilots repeatedly try to damage their airplane while in flight, to challenge themselves to create increasingly more interesting landings. But, besides the rhythm and music there, the words are also describing when you get that much deeper into a story and you've developed a deeper familiarity with the story's world that those outside this story might not share

"so i'm holding onto the details
capture this moment
in a series of carefully chosen words and phrases
and then replay it"
This is an interesting sorta meta realization and description of songwriting, the literal feeling of capturing a feeling.. or a memory ..or a memory being made there and then.

i basically poured my heart out in the previous couple of lines, and i understood that i'd probably completely submerged myself beyond any chance of getting myself back out in any 'normal'ish way, so, ....... i sort of figured i might as well become an alien at this point...... froze the harmony on a sort of ambiguosly not-really-stable but not-really-unstable, semi-awkward place, and then rigidly went to prose to literally explain what a diligent artist surely often tries to do, in situations where they encounter an inspiring situation or moment. simply try to capture it, like a scientist would capture some kind of specimen

"walk over the earth in special sandals
i kick those sandals off
and watch them fly around"

"i didn't notice

Of course alluding to the law of gravity, but also still (purposefully or not) tying in with the other apparent 'scientific' details in this song such as the sun's dwindling illumination and the moon's decorative origins.
actually, i was just trying to promote unconditional understanding. "if ____ happens, i'll understand." more of a spiritual vibe here

"oh, ah, oo, ee
the melody is drifting into the future"
The melody literally drifts into the future in spectacular key change faction. The vocal non-words are even rearranged so you really feel that 'oo'!
while also eagerly taking the chance to prove i did not copy-paste

about what time it  is
about what day it ever was and how it came to this"
A feeling of content with the past and how we got here, and maybe even a glimpse of hope for the future.

"the memory is drifting back in ways that i'll
pretend to know and understand
and i pretend to know exactly how the story will end"
Myself and I'm sure so many others know this feeling, it's so human to think, feel, and perhaps hope you know what will happen next. This completes the themes of storytelling within this song- from knowing what the story will be to pretending you know how it will end. And that story stretches beyond fiction into our own personal narratives, of the past, present and future. No one else really understands that narrative. That's  where art is sparked and discovered within and throughout and beyond. I really appreciate your music and what you do, thank you for the songs you write and the art you share.

do you think instrumental music can convey as much (or in some cases more) emotional impact or story to the listener as music with lyrics? i think it's a little sad that most people are aversive to listening to instrumentals by themselves.

music without words, scenes, or any other context, works mostly on your feelings and emotions, in a way that can be difficult to grasp if there's nothing to hold onto. it's extremely powerful, but it needs something to hold it. words can do this, scenes can do this, almost anything the music is attached to, can help hold the music and put it into context, and activate all of its power. and, at the same time, the music will greatly enhance the power of the thing it's attached to. Think of it like this: music is the beverage. the context/words/scene is the cup. imagine a beverage with no cup. same beverage...... undrinkable. Also, a cup without a beverage can be pretty bland also. Instead of being disappointed about this, i think you'll find it extremely rewarding to become a cupsmith. you'll be doing wonders for all different kinds of music, and cups as well. it's a win-win

whenever i'm in school i'll come up with crazy melodies and harmonies in my head but when i sit in fromt of my piano, nothing comes out. sometimes i can't even write my ideas down because they fade away so quickly. what should i do??

keep doing all this and eventually you'll find common ground. like dreams, the ideas want to come to you when you're not trying. that's why you freeze up when you are actually 'supposed to' have an idea. and why the ideas come so easily when it doesn't matter. these 2 opposing worlds (in-the-office, out-of-the-office) will probably always be disconnected like this. but the more you do both, the better you will get at both. for out-of-the-office, i think the game of capturing can always be improved. most of the time you are feeling like you are unable to capture it completely. because, like dreams, the best ideas probably happen when you are entirely not trying, and entirely not thinking nor worried. and as soon as you start worrying about capturing it, that will begin to degrade the idea. but i'd say over time you can just about get the hang of it with minimal degradation. And for the in-the-office experience, there are hopefully some things you can do to settle in and get more comfortable. I'd recommend starting out by playing/writing bad things on purpose, to try to take the pressure off. play at least enough to forget you're there. that should hopefully put you back in the proper carefree state

how did your new song "the ending" start off? when did you start writing it, how'd it come about?

during the selection process this time, i accidentally came up with  i (ref: write2022081013343412.mp3"target="_blank)something brand new which unexpectedly bypassed the entire selection process and was selected on the spot. no lyric, though, so, .... first thing was to begin searching for what lyric belongs on it. unfortunately, i think the pressure of liking the melody too much got to me and for some reason i was stuck on that for at least 2 days. i eventually got something that seemed to work, but it was not as title-worthy and iconic as i was hoping for. so in that case, i adopted more of a "just did a bad thing" strategy and just moved forward quickly. the "not worthy" part was also shocking to me, because it uses language and themes that i just absolutely don't recognize as my own. but that's actually fun when this happens because then the parts that come next will tend to have a "what the heck?" aspect to them, as they try to explain how the heck we got into this mess. turns into kind of an adventure story

i've noticed my favorite part in a lot of your recent songs is when a synth lead takes over (the lick in ground plane, after "celebration" in september, after "flagpole" in the new one). what is it about those parts that gets me so much / gets you enough to want to write them that way?

at some point, and i remember exactly where i was when i realized this, i realized: melodies with words, and melodies without words, when used side by side, can achieve an extraordinary strong effect. they give each other their meaning. if you sing a little thing (with words) and then play a little thing (wordless melody), they each make each other stronger. like cookies and milk. like curds and whey. pick your favorite snack. this phenomenon can actually be better than any snack. wordless riff, intermingled with worded riff is truly a power play and i can honestly say it improved the quality of my life when i realized this

holy moly bill can i maybe get a road map for the time sigs in your newest song, thanks

sure. there's probably many ways to do it, but here's how i would do it, if it were written down. tempo = 128.
4/4 for 4 bar instrumental intro
"getting ready..." 4/4, 4/4, 2/4
"weather"... 4/4, 4/4, 2/4, 4/4, 2/4  (*option to blow through in all 4)
"yes i'd" 4/4, 4/4, 4/4, 2/4, 2/4, 4/4, 2/4  (*that's the way it feels, but nevermind those two 2/4s in a row. that's probably stupid. just call it 4 there)
"out, i'm not worthy" 4/4 for 8 bars 
"ue, it's not true it's not true that's not true" 4/4 for 6 bars
"musical music" 4/4 for 4 bars
"don't really know" 4/4, 5/4, 4/4, 3/4, 4/4, 4/4 (or, if you are playing the cowbell here, perhaps you'd prefer a chart that just keeps it all in 4. vocalist or anyone playing along with the vocal riff would probably prefer to break it up into skips as shown)
"weep, skip" 4/4 for 4 bars
"slow it" 5/4, 6/4, 5/4, 4/4 HOLD (fermatta, but the recording specifically adds one additional bar of 5/8)
"riff" 4/4, 4/4, 4/4, 2/4
"more riff" 4/4, 4/4, 2/4, 4/4, 2/4 (*or, again, if you prefer you may skip this pair of 2/4s and cancel it out)
"i'm not worthy" 4/4 for 9 bars
"true" and vamp. 4/4 + 5/4 alternating until the end

Love the new song btw, it feels like its already becoming one of my favorites. Was there a certain inspiration behind "the ending" 's name or the theme of the song?

the verse melody is what started it all. i came up with it while i was busy trying to select one of my already existing ideas for what song to record next, but, that new melody hit me out of nowhere and shortcutted the entire selection process. the theme of the song came out of nowhere, and i actually was frustrated that i couldn't find a first line that was iconic enough for my liking. i was also assuming that the first line would be the title, but when i couldn't find anything good enough for that, i kind of hastily raced through the writing trying to outrun my discomfort of having to settle for the existing first line. i had no idea what the actual title would be, even well after i'd finished writing the song, and into production. i liked the "the ending" part of the song (the middle), but for some reason i didn't even notice that lyric when spending multiple times combing through every line in the song for an applicable title. finally when i was very near the end of the whole production process and had already begun throwing around totally extraneous titles, i combed through the lyrics one more time in search of a title and found that "the ending" part, right in plain sight, and it was an obvious title. but i didn't even notice this until i was just about done with the production of the song

the chorus of a new song seems surprisingly personal for bill wurtz song,

it's one of the least personal songs i've ever done. i don't know where it came from. The melody, for the verse, however, is extremely personal and i stand by that. never found a lyric that really captures what i honestly am feeling in that melody. the best expression of that line is when it's done instrumentally later. the staring at the flag pole is not quite genuine either, except actually given the circumstance, it is, if you account for the fact that i'm halfway through a song that did not necessarily start well (lyrically), so as i stare at the flag pole in this moment i can let the original melody come back to me, hopefully to catch a glimpse of it slightly closer to its original form
in a more obvious way than the way all of your songs are personal.

it's one of the least personal, but, the subtext is perhaps that i was possibly venting frustration that i never was able to come up with a title-worthy line for the first line melody in this particular song which i wrote 2 weeks ago. being stuck with a mostly un-relatable and disingenuous first line, i had no choice but to lean in harder and continue on writing more parts i don't relate to. however, it all fit into the fun game i've been playing, where i try to write songs as if i was another writer. it hopefully tricks me into coming up with new ideas

A couple weeks or months ago i asked a question because i found that every cool melodic idea i had seemed to go with a chord sequence that starts on the 4 chord. And i asked for advice on replicating the tension that starting on the 4 brings, without starting the chorus in all of my songs on the 4 chord. You suggested i transcribe a bunch of songs that i like to figure out what they're doing. I went through a big playlist i had of my favorite songs, and what i learned is, maybe i just really like songs with choruses that start on the 4?
that's understandable. i do too. a lot of people do
I went through 65 of them and 21 unambiguously had a chorus starting on the 4. Which seems like a lot. Another 15 of them started with a 6m into a 4, mostly going 6m 4 1 5.
yes, my research shows that's the most common sequence of them all

I don't tend to write a lot of songs with that progression because i wrote about a billion that way when i was younger. So that's over half of the songs (36/65) covered by the two harmonic ideas i am already doing way too much. Of the rest of the songs, wh ile they're good, they generally don't have the immediate tension that songs starting on the 4 do. Maybe it shouldn't be surprising that different chords sound different. But it seems like the best approach is either to deal with all my songs being a bit similar, or to accept that they won't be exciting in the same manner as (for example) Everytime We Touch.
